learning_outcomes.description: Formulate a significant and novel research question in or across the fields of doctrinal law, legal theory or socio-legal studies.
Design a research project to investigate that question using appropriate approaches to legal research and methodologies.
Utilise legal writing techniques that are appropriate to different academic aims and audiences.
Manage research projects to produce quality work within time-constraints.
Effectively present research to generate feedback on work-in-progress and disseminate findings from academics, a general audience and peers.

assessments.task_description:
The Research Proposal is a max 2,000-word description of your research project, which includes a draft outline of your research paper. The research proposal should identify the aims (question), scope and methodology/approach of the project, and position that project in its social and scholarly context.

Headings are included in the word count, as are quotations. Footnotes do not if they only contain references.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The Research Proposal should be submitted electronically on the Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
19/01/2026 - 23/01/2026

The exact time and place of the session will be posted on Blackboard at the start of semester.
assessments.task_description:
In this task, you will deliver a 15-minute presentation on your research projects, as they have evolved during the semester.

The presentation should illuminate the  core findings and significance of your research, while also explaining 1) what has changed and why in your research aims, questions, and method/approach over the semester; 2) what parts of the research and writing process came most easily and were most challenging; and 3) how your actual findings and argument varied from your expectations.

After each presentation there will be up to 15 mins Q&A, which is also assessable.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
The Research Paper presents the findings of the project as per the extended abstract. The word limits is 8,000 words (excl notes). Any material in excess of the word count will be disregarded by the marker, as well any substantive text in the footnotes.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The Research Paper must be submitted electronically on the Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 1(01 Dec - 07 Dec)
learning_activities.topic:
Getting started (Finalising supervision arrangements and self-directed learning)

In Week 1, students will begin working through the self-directed learning modules about legal research and writing (see Blackboard for details) and meet their supervisors for an initial discussion.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Getting started (Finalising supervision arrangements and self-directed learning)
learning_activities.topic_description: Getting started (Finalising supervision arrangements and self-directed learning) In Week 1, students will begin working through the self-directed learning modules about legal research and writing (see Blackboard for details) and meet their supervisors for an initial discussion.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 6(08 Dec - 18 Jan)
learning_activities.topic:
Independent research (Reading, Planning and Writing)

Between Weeks 2 and 6, students should be reading into their topics, planning and writing their proposal under the guidance of their supervisors.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Independent research (Reading, Planning and Writing) Between Weeks 2 and 6, students should be reading into their topics, planning and writing their proposal under the guidance of their supervisors.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 7 To Week 8(19 Jan - 01 Feb)
learning_activities.topic:
Independent Research and Meeting with Supervisor (Reading, Planning and Writing)

From Weeks 7 to 8, students will be undertaking independent research on their papers with guidance from their supervisors. The second compulsory meeting between students and supervisors must take place in this time, though multiple meetings will most likely be necessary for students to complete their Papers.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
